content: I recently posted this in the thread titled "TRAINS" in this General Discussion Forum and thought, "This could be a whole new thread!" Unfortunately, I can't see y’alls pictures, but having read this post has piqued my interest. For s-o-o long, I have looked at many items to convert into a nice living space. Since I live near a large navigatable river, I have lately considered converting a freight barge. These things have a HUGE base square footage to work with and a 2-story would definitely be do-able. However, for a land-based starter, train cars are great. While living in Kansas the past 18 years prior to moving here, I have seen an old wooden rail car sitting at the edge of a wheat field, and a couple of steel cabooses on other properties, as well as a few metal freight cars used as work areas for small businesses. I have considered large silos, (round rooms would be cool, but how do you put a child or grandchild in the corner for a time out?), barns, top floors of old brick buildings. In Hutchinson, Kansas; they have sold a couple of the old narrow firehouses (2-story) for residential properties and they would be cool. For legalities, they removed the brass pole for quick access from 2d floor to main floor...but person could put in a circular staircase or re-install a pole. :0) I'm curious about all types of "recycling” for living space...just 5 years until I will be forced to make a decision about something, somewhere. Whattayasay?? Anyone care to give alternate ideas to the traditional "house" building theme?? These are my opinions. Yours may differ.
reply: I recently posted this in the thread titled "TRAINS" in this General Discussion Forum and thought, "This could be a whole new thread!" Since I live near a large navigatable river, I have lately considered converting a freight barge. These things have a HUGE base square footage to work with and a 2-story would definitely be do-able. However, for a land-based starter, train cars are great. While living in Kansas the past 18 years prior to moving here, I have seen an old wooden rail car sitting at the edge of a wheat field, and a couple of steel cabooses on other properties, as well as a few metal freight cars used as work areas for small businesses. I have considered large silos, (round rooms would be cool, but how do you put a child or grandchild in the corner for a time out?), barns, top floors of old brick buildings. In Hutchinson, Kansas; they have sold a couple of the old narrow firehouses (2-story) for residential properties and they would be cool. For legalities, they removed the brass pole for quick access from 2d floor to main floor...but person could put in a circular staircase or re-install a pole. :0) I'm curious about all types of "recycling” for living space...just 5 years until I will be forced to make a decision about something, somewhere. Whattayasay?? Anyone care to give alternate ideas to the traditional "house" building theme?? These are my opinions. Yours may differ.
title: Alternate Living Quarters

content: Haven't done this myself, but I thought this guy's school bus conversion was fantastic: "http://www.vonslatt.com/bus-main.shtml
reply: Haven't done this myself, but I thought this guy's school bus conversion was fantastic: "http://www.vonslatt.com/bus-main.shtml
title: Alternate Living Quarters

content: I would love to. I have been looking at the old Conex shipping containers that we shipped thing around the world when I was in the Army. I would clear them for shipment for different movements the Army had. I went on a mission with the Army once and they set up all the K-9 gear and our gear inside one. A few guys hauled in thier bunks in and set them up. During the day they were very hot, but at night when it got cold the containers were real nice and warm. I bought one for storage and a few people have seen it and stopped by and told me how they were using them for camps in remote areas due being able to secure thier stuff when they leave. No one can break into them without a torch. This has really got me thinking. Bob Vila even likes the idea: "http://video.bobvila.com/m/21320567/floorplans-and-layout-of-the-container-house.htm
reply: I would love to. I have been looking at the old Conex shipping containers that we shipped thing around the world when I was in the Army. title: Alternate Living Quarters

content: You know, DAWG, they got those things sitting empty everywhere (the civilian ones), because no shipper is going to haul them back to point of origin empty, yet people are living in cardboard boxes! Those things can be stacked and bolted together. They ought to be used for temporary housing - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: You know, DAWG, they got those things sitting empty everywhere (the civilian ones), because no shipper is going to haul them back to point of origin empty, yet people are living in cardboard boxes! Those things can be stacked and bolted together. They ought to be used for temporary housing - - Wandering and Wondering
title: Alternate Living Quarters

content: You should see all the plans for changing them over to homes. I think you will see more of the Containers and Buses like OrangeKats in the future.
reply: You should see all the plans for changing them over to homes. I think you will see more of the Containers and Buses like OrangeKats in the future.

No one can break into them without a torch. This has really got me thinking. Bob Vila even likes the idea: "http://video.bobvila.com/m/21320567/floorplans-and-layout-of-the-container-house.htm There was an episode on TOH (This Old House) or some such where they are already using these in areas of Hurricane force winds and such because of their sturdiness and the fact that we import more than we export, so that there are thousands of these "available" if one can just cut through the middlemen and buy them direct from some major port or some such. These are my opinions. Yours may differ.

content: They are cheap right from the dealers. I think they start around $800 to $1200. Depending on size. I am getting another one in two weeks and i will give some firstr hand info then.

title: Alternate Living Quarters

content: PBS had a show on not long ago. Over in England they have entire apt complexes made of recycled containers. Most are made in China, so, whatch out for the lead content. It is cheaper for them to send them 1 way, then to return them to China for re-use. So, that kinda tells you, what you can pick up, has only been used once or twice.
reply: PBS had a show on not long ago. Over in England they have entire apt complexes made of recycled containers. Most are made in China, so, whatch out for the lead content. It is cheaper for them to send them 1 way, then to return them to China for re-use. So, that kinda tells you, what you can pick up, has only been used once or twice.

content: quote: Originally posted by mainedawg: I would love to. I have been looking at the old Conex shipping containers that we shipped thing around the world when I was in the Army. I would clear them for shipment for different movements the Army had. I went on a mission with the Army once and they set up all the K-9 gear and our gear inside one. I bought one for storage and a few people have seen it and stopped by and told me how they were using them for camps in remote areas due being able to secure thier stuff when they leave. No one can break into them without a torch. This has really got me thinking. Bob Vila even likes the idea: "http://video.bobvila.com/m/21320567/floorplans-and-layout-of-the-container-house.htm Here's a website with a little tech info: 'http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/ground/container.htm You'll notice that they're about 3300 lb. One problem I have with this sort of thing is that these projects are often done by people with little money, and they nasty up the contryside with their hasty configurations. I once owned an idyllic spot on a mountaintop in upstate New York. I went back to visit the area last year, and I couldn't believe the country-slum that had popped up there, with people living in buses, containers, and beater trailers. It's a sad commentary on the wealth of our nation.

reply: Here's a website with a little tech info: 'http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/ground/container.htm You'll notice that they're about 3300 lb. One problem I have with this sort of thing is that these projects are often done by people with little money, and they nasty up the contryside with their hasty configurations. I once owned an idyllic spot on a mountaintop in upstate New York. I went back to visit the area last year, and I couldn't believe the country-slum that had popped up there, with people living in buses, containers, and beater trailers. It's a sad commentary on the wealth of our nation.
title: Alternate Living Quarters

content: quote: Originally posted by sethkonigsbergrn: All's I can say is WOW!!
reply: All's I can say is WOW!!
title: Alternate Living Quarters

content: Bob Vila had a guy on one of his vidio's that has a 600 unit group he is working on in Cali. Some stand alone units and some 3 to 6 container unit groups. They have something here. I have veiwed many the last few days on the net.
